Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Improvement Award: Spatial Manifestations Of Social Identity

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
The primary objective of this research is to investigate the continual interplay that occurs between people and the spaces they construct as settlements change in size and scale. Archaeology provides a unique time depth for analyzing the processes of population aggregation and dispersal and can prove informative on a range of questions concerning the social implications of village life. How do previously dispersed social groups adjust to cohabitation? How is integration achieved and at what pace does it occur when new groups of people come together to construct new villages and other spatial units? Do certain events or forms of organization foreshadow village depopulation? This research attempts to better understand the negotiations among distinct groups as they begin sharing space. Research focused on architecture has revealed important aspects of cultural systems that shape and are shaped by their physical setting. Migration plays a major role in the world today -- for example in many regions of the developing world people flock from rural regions to reshape and expand cities -- and this proposed study of the past can provide insight into the process as it proceeds on a much expanded scale today.

Dr. E Charles Adams and Samantha Fladd will examine the strategies used by groups to modify their spatial setting and the social implications these choices have on the creation and dissolution of a community. Using excavation records from the 14th century ancestral Hopi villages of the Homol'ovi Settlement Cluster, architectural alterations, such as changing room size, internal features, and doorways, and the use of trash to fill rooms will be located spatially and temporally. Significant reorganization throughout the occupation of the villages and their eventual depopulation resulted in frequent architectural changes and the frequent deposition of cultural materials within rooms. Patterns in the composition and scale of these practices of modification will allow for distinctions to be made among social groups within the villages, as well as allow for the assessment of their relative interactions with one another. Depopulation of these villages was gradual and modifications to space, particularly the filling of rooms, illustrate this process. How these groups and relationships change throughout village occupation can reveal fluctuations in social organization that shed light on the relative success of strategies of integration during different phases of aggregation and dispersal. Detailed models of village aggregation and dissolution, applicable to historic and modern contexts, will be generated and a greater understanding of the history of the Homol'ovi Settlement Cluster will be of interest to scholars and descendant communities. Additionally, this research relies on records from previously excavated sites, furthering the ideals of preservation and stewardship central to archaeology and increasing the accessibility to the excavation documentation. Finally, the framework of this project forefronts the training of students in archaeological research and archival practices.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This research examines negotiations of social identity among groups residing in large Pueblos during the late Prehispanic period. This period (AD 1260-1400) was characterized by the aggregation of populations into discrete groupings of villages—settlement clusters—throughout the northern Southwest. Prior research generally focused on ceramic production and exchange networks, as well as architectural forms, to understand social relationships within and among settlement clusters. Building upon these studies, this work examines spatial manifestations of identity through patterns of modification to trace how social groups redefine their existence and relationships with one another at the three largest villages of the Homol’ovi Settlement Cluster, a group of ancestral Hopi pueblos in northeastern Arizona. There were three main project objectives: 1) the digitization of all excavation records pertaining to the three Homol’ovi villages; 2) the development of a methodology to examine spatial modifications archaeologically; and 3) the increased understanding of social group identities and interactions within these aggregated pueblos.

 

First, a digital archive of the paper excavation records from the work completed at Homol’ovi I, Homol’ovi II, and Chevelon Pueblo was created. The detailed excavations conducted by the Homol’ovi Research Program at the Homol’ovi Settlement Cluster are among the most extensive in the Southwest in recent decades. Each form was scanned and saved in a hierarchical system of folders organized by context. In total, over 18,000 documents were digitized resulting in over 9 GB of data on the three sites. Additionally, a searchable Excel database for the main excavation forms from each village was created. These efforts ensure the preservation of the excavation records and increase their accessibility for future research. Currently, the files are stored on two external hard drives and on the Arizona State Museum server housed by the Center for Computing and Information Technology at the University of Arizona. Upon completion of the co-PI’s dissertation, all data will be compiled into site documents for submission to the Digital Archaeological Record (tDAR) and made accessible to interested researchers at the discretion of the PI.

 

Second, spatial modifications were examined through architectural alterations and material deposition. Architectural alterations cover changes to the physical characteristics of a room, such as sealing doorways or adding/removing hearths, while material deposition refers to the placement of artifacts, sediments, and plants into rooms and can either prepare a space for construction, seal an unused feature or floor surface for subsequent remodeling, or fill a room to signal its closure once occupation of that space ends. As part of this research, a methodology—social syntax—was developed through the integration of aspects of spatial syntax, the biographical/life history approach, and practice theory. This methodology allows for a consideration of the spatial and temporal trends in groups’ interactions with space, incorporating depositional analyses with traditional architectural approaches. Applications of social syntax to Homol’ovi data highlight the strengths of this approach for reconstructing past social group identity.

 

Third, using qualitative and quantitative data from the excavation records, patterns of spatial modification across the villages were examined to understand the negotiation of the identities of social groups throughout occupation. The identities of the groups who occupied or used a space seem to be strong predictors for the later treatment of that space, suggesting a close association between people and rooms. Architectural remodeling often involves the replication of earlier internal room features and their placements, suggesting consistency in use over time. Material deposition that closed rooms mirrored the identity associated with that space during use; for example, rooms strongly associated with either men or women tend to serve as repositories for similarly gendered artifacts, often long after initial closure of the room. When use of a room changes drastically, such as a habitation room being converted to a ritual space or plaza, ceremonially-charged artifacts and ash are placed in high quantities in an effort to either signify the end of the prior uses or to prepare the space for future use. This project suggests cultural norms, social identities, and group relationships influenced room closure and produced spatial patterns demarcating different relationships with space. Although the occupants of individual rooms may not be the ones depositing materials, their identities continue to be associated with that space during subsequent interactions with the room. These findings highlight the deliberate and careful closure of rooms in Pueblo villages and the continued role of unoccupied spaces in subsequent negotiations of identity, supporting the strong and continuing ties between Homol’ovi and Hopi today.

 

Results from this project have been presented at several Society for American Archaeology conferences and at an Amerind Seminar. One peer-reviewed article has been published and future journal articles, book chapters, and a dissertation are currently in progress.
